documents.document: Women who are breastfeeding can now receive the COVID-19 vaccine when it is offered to them. If you have any concerns, speak to a healthcare professional before having the vaccination. More info: https://t.co/qAOGzpWMu6 https://t.co/57EJAhwZBl

Worrying too much can have a big impact on the way we feel. Visit #EveryMindMatters for a range of specific tips and expert advice to help you manage feelings of anxiety: https://t.co/cUgudRCBI9 https://t.co/mz57aFIT2M

Pregnancy can impact your mental health in many ways, even if this isn't your first time. You are not alone and support is available. Find advice about how to look after your mental health in pregnancy: https://t.co/2HRtaRFMom #WorldMaternalMentalHealthDay #WMMHDay #MMHWeek https://t.co/DseTQyupL0

Remember F.A.S.T for the signs someone might be having a stroke. Face has their face fallen on one side? Can they smile? Arms can they raise both arms and keep them there? Speech is it slurred? Time its time to call 999. When stroke strikes remember to Act F.A.S.T. https://t.co/O8ODTeZgVu
The COVID-19 vaccine has already saved thousands of lives. Don't delay in getting your vaccine when it's offered to you. Find out more https://t.co/ATVQU3x9J3 https://t.co/FeEDT3yCYE

@Fifi_Borgia (2/2) The COVID-19 vaccines were only approved once they met robust standards of effectiveness, safety and quality.

@Fifi_Borgia (1/2) The safety of the public will always come first. The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is the UKs independent regulator, their role is to ensure medicines, devices and vaccines work and are safe for use.
@TBlighe @thedartswidow (2/2) The COVID-19 vaccines were only approved once they met robust standards of effectiveness, safety and quality.

@TBlighe @thedartswidow (1/2) The safety of the public will always come first. The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is the UKs independent regulator, their role is to ensure medicines, devices and vaccines work and are safe for use.
@kiki123_o @thedartswidow (2/2) The COVID-19 vaccines were only approved once they met robust standards of effectiveness, safety and quality.

@kiki123_o @thedartswidow (1/2) The safety of the public will always come first. The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is the UKs independent regulator, their role is to ensure medicines, devices and vaccines work and are safe for use.

@S__KETC (4/4) The data looked at includes all the results from lab studies, clinical trials, manufacturing and quality controls and testing the product. The public can be very confident that all those tests are done to the very highest standards.

@S__KETC (3/4) Right through the tests and the trials, teams of scientists and clinicians carefully, methodically, scientifically and rigorously review all data on safety, effectiveness and quality as soon as they become available.
@S__KETC (2/4) The COVID-19 vaccines were only approved once they met robust standards of effectiveness, safety and quality.

@S__KETC (1/4) The safety of the public will always come first. The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is the UKs independent regulator, their role is to ensure medicines, devices and vaccines work and are safe for use.

@TinaBr2 (4/4) The data looked at includes all the results from lab studies, clinical trials, manufacturing and quality controls and testing the product. The public can be very confident that all those tests are done to the very highest standards.

@TinaBr2 (3/4) Right through the tests and the trials, teams of scientists and clinicians carefully, methodically, scientifically and rigorously review all data on safety, effectiveness and quality as soon as they become available.
@TinaBr2 (2/4) The COVID-19 vaccines were only approved once they met robust standards of effectiveness, safety and quality.

@TinaBr2 (1/4) The safety of the public will always come first. The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is the UKs independent regulator, their role is to ensure medicines, devices and vaccines work and are safe for use.

@GoonerRichB The UK operates a system of informed consent for vaccinations. Vaccines are the most effective way to prevent infectious diseases; however, it is up to individuals to decide whether they want to receive a vaccine or not. There's more info here: https://t.co/jKMHsJHocp

@B93972428 The Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine is safe, effective, and has already saved thousands of lives. The UKs independent regulator, the MHRA, and the JCVI have both said that the benefits of the vaccine far outweigh the risks for the vast majority of adults.

@nikkijfox Hi Nikki. We're working on providing people with the ability to show their Covid-status through digital and non-digital routes, with security and privacy at the core of this approach. Use of the NHS App is being considered as part of the digital route.

@wilkina50 You can tell us if it's any good, or if there's anything we could do to make it work better or make it easier for others to use. Gathering feedback from people who will use something is incredibly valuable as it'll make a service better and more useful.

@mandm280511 Hello MM. COVID-19 vaccines were tested on 30,000 people from all walks of life and have been part of the trials. The Government has accepted the recommendation from the independent Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) to approve the COVID-19 vaccinations.
